Exercise 5.2.3: if is non-zero, then ; conversely, for real numbers , there exists a non-zero with and .

theorem exercise_5_2_3 : ( f : {h : // Continuous h Function.Periodic h 1}, f.1 0 0 < periodicL2Norm f periodicL2Norm f periodicLInftyNorm f) ( A B : , 0 < A A B f : {h : // Continuous h Function.Periodic h 1}, f.1 0 periodicL2Norm f = A periodicLInftyNorm f = B) := by constructor intro f hne refine helperForExercise_5_2_3_nonzero_implies_l2_pos f hne, helperForExercise_5_2_3_l2_le_lInfty f intro A B hA hAB by_cases hEq : A = B subst hEq exact helperForExercise_5_2_3_exists_exact_norms_on_diagonal A hA have hLt : A < B := lt_of_le_of_ne hAB hEq exact helperForExercise_5_2_3_exists_exact_norms_strict A B hA hLt
